Hi!

Often, a few thoughts are worth much more than an official positions.

That's a good point about keeping the two tests in different folders. I
suppose I'll have to go find  a Maven plugin for other types of tests as
well now :)

I'm also beginning to think that integration testing is of great importance,
especially since my projects are getting quite complicated (simulated
compilers and such for University). Thus my interest. I think I'll
definitely check out the relative merits of trying first a simple JUnit
approach to intergration testing and then trying the TestNG route.

Thanks for the tips regarding User Acceptance testing. I was pretty sure
JUnit isn't the right approach here. I'll check out those tools, since I
concur about readability - especially for agile shops.

As for getting the 'feel' of TDD, I know exactly what you mean. I've learned
a lot over the past year or so of using it, and it's sped up my development
efforts greatly.

Thanks again,
Jan.

2008/9/2 Dennis Lloyd Jr <dennislloydjr@...>

>   Hi Jan,
> I won't claim to be the official position of the JUnit community, but I
> will
> offer my thoughts.
>
> It is okay to use JUnit for other kinds of testing, however I avoid putting
> my unit tests and integration or system tests in the same source folders.
> The reason for this is, I'd rather be able to run my unit tests very
> frequently and therefore they need to be very fast. Separating them allows
> me to pick what to run.
>
> Honestly, I've been giving some thought to the concept of integration
> testing and wondering myself where it fits in (after some thought-provoking
> comments from Joe Rainsberger). Right now my thinking is that it is a
> valuable testing practice to do white-box integration testing and
> automating
> those tests using a tool such as JUnit is probably a good idea. However,
> I'm
> not sure that TDD integration testing is the right thing - anyone else have
> thoughts on this? (Maybe I should start another thread...)
>
> As for user acceptance tests, I try not to do these in JUnit at all. The
> reason is, I want the user to be able to read them. Therefore, I use tools
> such as Fitnesse, and now I'm trying out Concordian.
>
> Ultimately you'll need to find what works for you and your team, and you'll
> probably change your strategy several times as you learn the 'feel' of TDD.
> It takes some time to learn, but has been the most valuable practice I've
> found in software design. Welcome to TDD.
>
> Hope this helps!
> -Dennis
>
>
